metadata.title: Micro- and Nano-Structured Vanadium Pentoxide (V2O5) for Electrodes of Lithium-Ion Batteries

sections.text:
www.advenergymat.de
Review
1602545 (1 of 32) © 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
Micro- and Nano-Structured Vanadium Pentoxide (V2O5) for Electrodes of Lithium-Ion Batteries
Yuan Yue and Hong Liang*
DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201602545
deficiency. The exclusive research and industrial focus on the development of new energy sources cannot meet the current energy demands. The main reason is lack of efficient storage of the collected energy. Because the consumption rate of generated energy usually cannot be synchronized with the rate of generation. Fortunately, this problem has received attention from researchers and engineers around the world. Electrochemical energy storage devices (EESDs)[1,2] are competitive candidates for energy storage. Lithiumion batteries (LIBs),[3–11] electron double layer capacitors (EDLCs) as well as pseudocapacitors (PCs),[12–17] lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries,[18–22] lithium–air (Li–air) or lithium–oxygen (Li–O2) batteries,[23–29] sodium-ion batteries,[30–33] magnesium-ion batteries,[34] lithium solid state batteries,[35] among others are currently popular EESDs. Among those devices, lithium-ion batteries are of great interest. Since being initially commercialized by Sony, Inc. in 1990,[36] for more than a quarter of a century, the lithium-ion battery has become
a popular, portable, and rechargeable second battery used in various applications such as personal electronic devices,[37] electric vehicles,[38] hybrid electric vehicles,[39] and smart grids.[40] To date, it is still needed to further improve the electrochemical performance of lithium-ion batteries. The fabrication of novel and reliable electrode materials is critical for further development of better lithium-ion batteries.
A lithium-ion battery cell usually includes components of a solid-state positive electrode (cathode), a solid-state negative electrode (anode), some lithium-ion included liquidstate electrolyte (can be either non-aqueous or aqueous[41]), a polymeric separator, and a pair of the current collectors with encapsulated cases.[3] If an external voltage applied to both electrodes, lithium ions are deintercalated from cathode to anode through the electrolyte, so called the charging process; when there is an external loading applied to both electrodes, lithium ions are intercalated into unlithiated cathode from lithiated anode through the electrolyte again, i.e., the discharging process.[3,39,42] The discharging procedure of a LIB cell is shown in Figure 1.[39] The role of the porous separator is to prevent the short circuit inside a cell. As the most significant components of one lithium-ion battery cell, the properties of both cathode and anode materials determine the electrochemical energy storage ability of the cell. Therefore, the selection of
Vanadium pentoxide (V2O5) has played important roles in lithium-ion batteries due to its unique crystalline structure. To assist researchers understanding the roles this material plays, a comprehensive and critical review is conducted based on about 250 publications. Here, we report basics and applications of micro- and nano-materials of V2O5 and V2O5-based composites. The comparative and statistical analysis leads to the discovery of several interesting phenomena. The V2O5 electrodes with two lithium ions have a favorable capacity performance with reversible phase formation. The excellent capacity retention is displayed in the V2O5 electrodes with one lithium ion inserted. In the case of three lithium ions insertion, it was found that the irreversible formation of the phase ω in LixV2O5 leads to its control. In addition, effects of additives on electrode performance, circuitry models of performance, as well as reaction routes are studied. Two unprecedented concepts of the “high capacity band” and “empirical total capacity retention” are proposed though the comprehensive statistical analysis of the reviewed data. This review provides a comprehensive collection of information of state-ofthe-art and recent advancement in V2O5 and V2O5-based composite materials for electrodes. Researchers could use the information to design and develop advanced electrodes for future batteries.
Lithium-Ion Batteries

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Since the early 21st century, using energy more efficiently and saving the limited energy sources have become critical worldwide. In recent years, researchers have been striving to discover new means to create energy sources. For example, energies from solar heating, photovoltaics, nuclear fission and fusion, wind blowing, hydropower, tidal fluctuation, biomass, and geothermal collection, are favorable alternatives to replace the conventional combustion of fossil fuel. Scientific breakthroughs and technological innovations have been reported with increasing rate. The development of the advanced energy storage methods is very crucial to resolve the issue of energy

www.advenergymat.de
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1602545 (2 of 32)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
the electrode materials is a profound topic needs to be investigated. According to the illustration of Figure 1, it is apparent that both electrodes needs to be layered structure such that the lithium ions have sufficient spaces to be intercalated.[39,43,44] For anodes, the carbonaceous materials such as bulk/powder graphite, carbon black, and graphene are widely applied to LIB cells due to their layered structure and high reversibility of lithium insertions;[43,45] For cathode, lithium transition metal oxides (LTMOs)[6] are favorable to be selected, because of their layered structure, high theoretical specific capacity, high electrochemical potential versus Li/Li+, acceptable reaction reversibility, among others.[3,46] There are several LTMOs such as LiCoO2,[47,48] LiNiO2,[49] Li(Ni1/3Mn1/3Co1/3)O2,[50] LiMn2O4,[51] LiFePO4,[52] which have become common cathode materials of LIBs cells for nearly two decades. Nevertheless, the restricted capacity and cyclic performance of such bulk-sized conventional LTMOs cathode materials prompt to discover novel micro- and nano-structures in order to improve the performance of LIB cells.[53] Various transition metal oxide (TMO) nanomaterials that do not include lithium atoms have attracted increasing attention. The main reasons are their high specific surface area, novel size effect, shorter ion diffusion pathway, obviously enhanced reaction kinetics, among others.[5,54] Co3O4,[55] Cr2O3,[56] CuO,[57] Fe2O3,[58] MnO2,[59] NiO,[60] SnO2,[61] TiO2 (both anatase[62] and rutile[63]), V2O5,[64–67] and ZnO.[68] Those TMOs have unique performance as cathodes since their properties of the molar masses, theoretical specific capacities, melting points, densities, and the insertion numbers of lithium ions are different. Figure 2 shows the comparison of theese properties in a three-dimensional (3D) bubble plot with color mapping. In the 3D plot, the properties of V2O5 in terms of tunable number of the inserted lithium ions, lower density, and lower melting temperature are exhibited. However, other TMOs such as ZnO, CuO, NiO, SnO2, TiO2, etc. usually have lower lithium ion(s) insertion/extraction potential than that of V2O5. This could result in a higher risk for TMOs to be reduced to metal during the lithium intercalation reactions. Furthermore, the compound of V2O5 has the advantages of the wide lithiation/ delithiation potential windows, ease to prepare, and abundant amount from the mineral storage. These advantages promote the highly concentrated research interests in the usage of V2O5 as electrochemical energy storage devices. Thus, developing V2O5 nanomaterials possessing novel structures and architectures is continuously attractive. Numerous published research results that are related to the V2O5 and V2O5-based composites as electrodes can be found. Because V2O5 is a transition metal oxide, most of the published results related to the V2O5 as LIB electrodes are about cathodes. This review will therefore focus on the cathodes containing V2O5 and V2O5 composites.
There are many reports found about V2O5 electrodes including several review articles about electrochemical properties of V2O5.[64,70–74] Most published articles focus on specific properties or topical areas.[72,75,76] However, no published review or progress articles have provided systematic analysis of the electrochemical performance of V2O5 as electrodes of LIBs. In this article, both fundamental knowledge of V2O5 on crystallography and electrochemistry and the performance of V2O5 cathodes in the application of LIBs are reviewed with critical analysis. This paper starts with a review of basics about crystalline structure and electrochemical property of V2O5, and then the current research of V2O5 will be summarized with the categorization based on the lithium ion insertion number by micro- or nanostructured V2O5 electrodes. The current research results of the V2O5-based materials and other vanadium oxide (VOx) as LIB cathodes will be reviewed as the following content. Next, the results of analysis about the electrochemical performance of V2O5 and V2O5-based materials will be demonstrated through a series of figure panels and plots. Meanwhile, figures and tables will also be provided to illustrate the electrochemical performance of both hierarchical and un-hierarchical V2O5 and V2O5-based electrodes. Through data analysis, it was found that the value of the preferred applied current density was moderate (around 30≈500 mA g–1). An empirical coefficient of the total capacity retention was proposed. Statistical analysis indicated that the insertion mode of one intercalated lithium ion was found to have the highest value of total capacity retention. Detailed discussion is provided below based on the electrochemical features of V2O5 electrodes. The diverse and systematic analysis based on the published data of reviewed results is the most innovative part of this paper. The corresponding finding and proposing of concepts can offer a comprehensive and analytical overview for the researchers in related fields.
Yuan Yue received his B.S. degree in Applied Physics from the Physics Elite Class at Xi’an Jiaotong University (China) in 2013. He is currently a Ph.D. candidate at the Department of Materials Science and Engineering in Texas A&M University. He is currently working in the Surface and Interface Science Group under Professor Hong
Liang. His research interests include novel nanoparticles and nanocomposites used to develop novel electrodes for applications in electrochemical energy storage and sensing devices.
Hong Liang is professor of Mechanical Engineering and Materials Science & Engineering, Texas A&M University. She has been a faculty member for more than a decade and a half. She conducted postdoc research at National Institute of Technology after finishing Ph.D. at Stevens Institute of Technology. Her research
group has been actively involved in design, synthesis, fabrication, and characterization of novel nanoparticles, nano-structured materials and devices.

Finally, prospects for future research is given at the last section.
2. Basis of V2O5 as Electrodes of LIBs
Vanadium is a common transition metal and has four oxidation states of V2+, V3+, V4+, and V5+[69] being associated with oxides of VO, V2O3, VO2, and V2O5 respectively. The physical and material properties of these four oxidation states are listed in Table 1. Distinct lattice systems and valence states permute their unique properties. The first indication is the color as shown in Table 1 in an aqueous solution of ions such as V2+, V3+, V4+, and V5+, which is violet, green, blue, and yellow corresponding to different optical characteristic wavelengths.[77] A redox reactions can be identified first handedly with the color. Furthermore, vanadium oxides can be categorized into two families. The first is the VnO2n+1 family, which consists of V3O7, V4O9, and V6O13;[78] the other is the VnO2n−1 family composed of V4O7, V5O9, V6O11, V7O13, and V8O15. These oxides usually possess combined oxidation states of vanadium and complicated crystalline structures. Vanadium is one of the most abundant element in the earth’s crust.[79–81] This makes the manufacturing and its usage at very low-cost. Because vanadium pentoxide (V2O5) is the most common oxide of vanadium, this article will focus on the properties of vanadium pentoxide as an LIB cathode. Furthermore, according to recently published results,[82–85] the effect of the toxicity of V2O5 to human cannot be neglected. According to the literature, inhalation or the industrial exposure to V2O5 would cause the clinic consequences related to the damage of the skin and the respiratory system, especially lung damages. Some other poisoning symptoms such as the greenish-black discoloration of the tongue, palpitation on exertion, and tremor of the finger and arms are also possible to emerge after inhaling V2O5 particles. In this case, the experimental operation with V2O5 should be extremely cautious with reliable protections.
The unique layered arrangement of the crystalline structure of V2O5 provides the inserted space for intercalated lithium ions. Figure 3a depicts the 3D sketch of the crystalline structure of V2O5 along with its projected sketch from three axes. The V2O5 has a well-defined orthorhombic phase (space group Pmmn No. 59). The mutually orthogonal lattice vectors a, b, and c have

the lengths of a = 11.516 Å, b = 3.5656 Å, and c = 4.3727 Å, respectively. The typical X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of orthorhombic V2O5 is illustrated in Figure 4a. The standard pattern number is JCPDS No. 41–1426.[86] It is straightforward to see that V2O5 has a layered crystalline structure. The layered structure of V2O5 is constructed by the layers of series of VO5 pyramids with distorted apices. These pyramids are in series in the planes of (00l). In every pyramid, a vanadium atom is embedded by five oxygen atoms, five V–O single bonds connect the vanadium atom to oxygen atoms. Among pyramids in the same layer, every oxygen atom is bonded by two or three vanadium atoms depending on its position. Within a series of the pyramids, positions of the oxygen atoms at the apices of pyramids alternate in the sequence of up-up-down-down. Furthermore, there is a weak V–O interaction between the oxygen atom at the apices of a pyramid and the vanadium atom within that in the adjacent layer.[70] This interlayered interaction that perpendicular to the c-axis maintain the layered character of the V2O5. After introducing the lithium ions into the interlayered spaces of V2O5, a series of the phase transformations will occur, which leading to the change of the crystalline structure as well as electrochemical energy storage.
It is noted that V2O5 has multiple phases formed successively with the progress of lithiation. Figure 3b,c illustrate the structure change of the vanadium pentoxide before (V2O5) and after lithiation process (LixV2O5).[87] The distorted pyramid structure of pristine V2O5 can be preserved during the lithiation, but the smooth layers owned by pristine V2O5 will have
more puckering with the increasing insertion number x.[91] Usually for V2O5, the value of x cannot exceed three and five phases are divided according to the difference of values of x and the crystalline structure, i.e., α-LixV2O5 (0 < x < 0.01); ε-LixV2O5 (0.35 < x < 0.7); δ-LixV2O5 (0.7 < x < 1); γ-LixV2O5 (1 < x < 2); ω-LixV2O5 (2 < x < 3).[87,91,92] There are four phase transformation electrochemical reactions between the adjacent phases. Table 2 gives detailed information of those four reactions that have different equilibrium potentials. In the real lithium ion intercalation process, i.e., the discharging process of an LIB cell, reactions of from α to ω with the descending potential versus Li/Li+. On the contrary, the back reactions from γ to α will occur when the lithium ion deintercalate from LixV2O5 and applying ascending voltages. The formation of ω-LixV2O5 phase is sometimes irreversible.[91,90]
The successive phase transformations of LixV2O5 lead to the tunable insertion numbers of lithium ions. From the x value spans among five phases of LixV2O5, the first lithium ion insertion occurs at the phase transformations of α → ε and ε → δ; the second lithium ion insertion occurs at δ → γ; the third lithium ion insertion occurs at γ → ω. The method of cyclic voltammetry (CV) is convincing to characterize the insertion number of the LixV2O5 phases. Figure 4b–d plot the typical CV curves of the lithium ions insertion/extraction procedures of x values of 1, 2, and 3, respectively. In Figure 4b,[88] if the CV test is deployed with the voltage range of 2.5≈4 V, two reaction troughs with voltages of 3.33 V and 3.08 V are obvious to be observed from the discharge/insertion curve

(lower one), which are corresponding to α → ε and ε → δ. Two reaction peaks in the upper charge/extraction curve reveal the back reactions as δ → ε and ε → α. According to Figure 4c,[89] when the discharge/insertion voltage continues to decrease after reaching 2.5 V versus Li/Li+, one more reaction trough of 2.2 V emerges, implying the formation of the phase γ from δ. The corresponding charge/extraction peak will occur at 2.5 V. Figure 4d[90] exhibits that if the lowest potential deceases to 1.5 V, the third lithium ion is inserted and a trough of 1.9 V will be generated. The formation of phase ω is irreversible due to no obvious and sharp reduction peaks can be detected in the upper charge/extraction curve. In general, there are three applied voltage windows which can be selected according to requirement in the real case. Different voltage windows as well as insertion numbers of lithium ions can result in different specific capacities. Equation (1) describes the calculation to derive the theoretical specific capacity of an electrode active material for LIB cells.[2]
26.8 C n

where n is the number of moving electron, i.e., the number of inserted lithium ions in redox reactions; M is the mole mass of the active material. The number 26.8 is the Faraday constant with the unit of A h, which is 26.8 A h = 96500 C = NAe, where NA is the Avogadro constant and e the charge of an electron. According to Equation (1), we can derive for the material of V2O5 as LIB electrodes in three cases of insertion numbers. Number one, the narrow voltage window (2.5≈4 V) can provide one lithium ion insertion, which has the theoretical specific capacity of 147 mA h g–1. Number two, the intermediate voltage window (2≈4 V) can offer spaces for two lithium ions with the theoretical specific capacity of 294 mA h g–1. Number three, the wide voltage window (1.5≈4 V) can give three lithium ions available insertion sites and the corresponding theoretical specific capacity of 441 mA h g–1. This is the core for the tunable performance of the V2O5 electrodes for LIBs. In the next section, electrodes composed by micro- and nano-structured V2O5 will be reviewed chronologically along with the categorization of the insertion numbers of lithium ions from one to three.

sections.heading: 3. Micro- and Nano-Structures of V2O5 LIB Electrodes
sections.text:
3.1. V2O5 Electrodes With one Li+ Insertion
The lithiation mode of one lithium ion insertion of V2O5 electrodes has been reported lately. As the insertion mode of the fewest lithium ions, the working potential window of the V2O5 electrodes with one lithium ion insertion is usually in 2.5≈4 V. According to Table 2, LixV2O5 phases of α, ε and δ can be formed. Table 3 summarizes published work on V2O5 electrodes with one lithium ion insertion. As listed, electrodes reach the maximum specific capacity around 130≈147 mA h g–1 under mild current density loading (100≈2000 mA g–1). Their cyclic performance can be summarized as fading less than 0.03 % per cycle if the test undergoes 500 cycles or fewer. Representative examples of such V2O5 electrodes with featured morphologies are displayed through panels of Figure 5. Initially, Ng et al. synthesized nanoparticles (Figure 5a) of V2O5 by flame spray pyrolysis. The uniformly size-distributed nanoparticles whose diameters were 30≈60 nm in this work. The highlight of the experimental route was the application of the optimized precursor concentration and injection rate. The enhanced electrochemical performance as the specific capacity of 141 mA h g–1 at the first cycle was measured.[67] Later, the novel morphologies such as porous and hierarchical structures or shape-specific particles started to be synthesized by numerous researches. This development promoted the emerging of fruitful morphologies of V2O5 electrodes with advanced performance. In 2011, Wang et al. published a result of the 3D porous thin film with the component of V2O5 exclusively through electrostatic spray deposition.[93] The morphology illustrated in Figure 5b was obtained through controlling the deposition temperature and deposition time. The morphological evolution from the initial layered two-dimensional (2D) reticular structure to 3D porous multideck-cage porous was clearly observed.[93] Excellent capacity and cyclic performance could be attributed to their unique porous structure that improves electrolyte infiltration and optimizes lithium ion diffusion.
Shape-specific V2O5 nanostructures have been fabricated for the usage of LIB electrodes. Wang and co-workers[88] prepared shape-selective one-dimensional (1D) V2O5 nanostructures
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 7, 1602545
www.advenergymat.de
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1602545 (7 of 32)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
using the electrospinning technique with the identical reagent. Different annealing temperatures of 400, 500, and 600 °C resulted in the 1D morphologies of porous nanotubes (Figure 5c), hierarchical nanofibers (Figure 5d), and singlecrystalline (along [001]) nanorods, respectively (Figure 5e). The intersected 1D morphology provided more reaction and diffusion sites for the intercalated lithium ions. The singlecrystalline nanorods stood out in both cycling and capacity performance among the three different samples. The maximum specific capacity of 163 mA h g–1 possessed was even higher than the theoretical value. Authors demonstrated that such superior results were due to the favorable crystal orientations. The suppressed thickness of nanorods along the [001] direction could withstand significant stress without disintegration,[104] which resulted in the good tolerance of the cycled lithiation/ delithiation procedures. As shown in Figure 5f, ultrathin layers with the well-defined crystalline 2D morphology was synthesized through supercritical solvothermal reactions (An and coauthors[98]). The maximum specific capacity of 146 mA h g–1 with small capacity fading was achieved by this electrode of nanosheets. This was the due to the large specific surface area of the ultrathin nanosheets and thus fast ion diffusion.
The addition of nanopores can improve the electrochemical performance. A novel morphology of 3D porous microplates with dart-like shape (Figure 5g) was prepared by An et al. in 2014.[100] The solvothermal reaction of NH4VO3 and urea resulted in the product of 3D hexagonal V2O5 microplates with curved edges. The dart-like V2O5 microplates were eventually obtained through the thermal decomposition of ammonium group with the releasing of the ammonia gas and leaving of abundant vacant pores. Such a porous structure was the key to make this sample having a maximum specific capacity of 146 mA h g−1. This dart-like sample became a competitive electrode choice because of the numerous pores on the surface.[100] Those pores could improve the electrolyte penetration efficiency and increase the interface area between the solid electrode and the liquid electrolyte. Another example is based on the result by Wang et al.[99] They fabricated 3D hierarchical and porous microspheres (Figure 5h) using refluxing approach followed by annealing in air. These porous microspheres were composed of a large amount of intertwined laminar nanoparticles whose dimension were approximately 200 nm. This porous structure provided the enlarged surface area, shorter ion diffusion lengths, more available buffering space for the volume expansion/extraction. As a result favorable electrochemical properties of 142 mA h g–1 of the maximum specific capacity and 0.28% of the capacity fading after 100 cycles was achieved.[99] An and co-workers reported two results in 2015 referred to the
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 7, 1602545
www.advenergymat.de
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1602545 (8 of 32)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
innovative V2O5 electrodes. The first one was the 3D interconnected nanonetworks with layered structure (Figure 5i).[101] This structure, prepared by gelling process of V2O5 sol–gel, caused effective and continuous charger transport as well as the reduced ion diffusion pathway. The ability of preventing cyclic volume change during the intercalation/deintercalation steps was also enhanced. Thus a maximum specific capacity of 149 mA h g–1 could be attained by this interconnected nanonetwork. The second was the morphology of 3D porous octahedrons (Figure 5j). The gradual surface reaction of the decomposition from (NH4)2V3O8 to V2O5 was the source of the octahedron formation. The porous structure emerged after the residual of ammonium group was released as ammonia gas during the calcination. The promising performance of the maximum specific capacity of 135 mA h g–1 due to porous octahedrons could be ascribed to their increased surface area and

3.2. V2O5 Electrodes With Two Li+ Insertion
The intercalation mode of two lithium ions inserted are the most typical mode of the application of V2O5 to LIB cells. Table 4 summarizes recently published research related to V2O5 electrodes with the two insertion of intercalated lithium ions. The moderate selection of the applied voltage window and the stable formation of the phase γ can be summarized as the main reason. Due to the two intercalation sites available of phase γ, the theoretical specific capacity is 294 mA h g–1. More than half of the reviewed electrode prototypes in Table 4 possess the maximum specific capacity exceeding 275 mA h g–1. The cyclic performance of them can be eliminated as smaller than 0.5% faded per cycle when the cycles number is 50≈100. Ten typical cases among them are selected and exhibited as a panel gallery of Figure 6. Figure 6a is a SEM photograph of the 1D uniform V2O5 nanobelts fabricated by Glushenkov et al. in 2008.[104] Nanobelts grown along the [010] direction were fabricated through the process of ball milling of commercial V2O5 powders followed by annealing. Each as-prepared nanobelt had two main facets of (001) surrounded by vertical facets of (100), (010), and (310).[104] The performance of specific capacity particularly the cycle fading of these V2O5 nanorods were excellent as 275 mA h g–1 and 0.08% after 50 cycles, respectively. This can be ascribed to the small size with suppressed thickness along [001] direction and beneficial crystal orientation of (001) facet of these nanorods. As a novel morphology, the micro- or nanoparticles with yolk–shell structures using Ostwald ripening methods[105–110] are prepared frequently in recent decades. In 2011, Liu and co-workers prepared V2O5 electrode samples of 3D uniform yolk–shell microspheres through a simple solvothermal route.[111] The Ostwald ripening process took place in the elevated temperature and pressure conditions during the solvothermal route. Figure 6b exhibits the uniform size, smooth surface, and solid spherical yolks embedded by semitransparent shells of this sample. Owing to the better structure for the ion transport and good maintenance of the shape after frequent volume changes, these yolk–shell V2O5 microspheres achieved 280 mA h g–1 as the maximum specific capacity and 0.7% as the capacity fading.[111] Wang et al. created a method to assemble long V2O5 nanobelts into 2D membrane structure by mediated hydrogen bonding action.[112] As shown in Figure 6c, the intersected nanobelts formed the large-area capsule-like porous membrane with uniform thickness around 1 µm. This assembly using the linking of hydrogen bonding could preserve the good crystalline structure of V2O5 nanobelts.[112] The maximum specific capacity of 290 mA h g–1 could be characterized thanks to multiple aspects. Firstly, a large amount of well-crystallized V2O5 nanobelts provided more well-defined reaction sites and diffusion spaces after the assembly; secondly, the nanobelt morphology possessed uniform facets of (110) to enhance the lithiation and delithiation processes; finally, the interconnected network feature of the membrane offered more available pathway of the conducting of electrons, which could improve the energy transport efficiency. Another example of
the assembled architecture of V2O5 nanomaterials was the work accomplished by Pan and co-authors.[113] This 3D hierarchical urchin-like microflowers were assembled by the 1D nanosheets as building blocks, which were the “flower petals” illustrated in Figure 6d. Through the manipulation of the VOC2O4 reagent concentrations and the reaction time lengths during the process of the solvothermal reaction, the optimal flower morphology could be prepared. These micro-flowers possessed the maximum specific capacity of 274 mA h g–1 and the capacity fading of 0.4% after 50 cycles. Larger surface area, enough vacant pores to facilitate the electrolyte penetration, and the reduced diffusion path of ions resulted in the excellent performance of 3D urchin-like microflowers.
Two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets are another family of the nanostructured V2O5 as electrodes of LIBs. Wang et al. prepared a kind of large-area 2D nanosheets of V2O5 (Figure 6e) through a facile dissolution–splitting method.[122] The as-prepared V2O5 nanosheets were separated by the calcination of the (NH4)2V6O16 stacked nanosheets, which were the product of the dissolution–splitting reaction from layered V2O5 commercial powder. The as-prepared V2O5 nanosheets were 10≈20 nm in thickness and several micrometers in lateral size. The crystalline structure of nanosheets were dominated by the (001) facet of the Shcherbinaite phase (JCPDS card No. 65–0131).[122] The ultrafine nanosheet structure of highly uniform facet orientation brought out a high interfacial contact area between solid electrode and liquid electrolyte and a shorter lithium charger diffusion/transportation length. This was the reason for the favorable performance of 268 mA h g–1 (maximum specific capacity) and 0.66% (capacity fading when applied 50 cycles). Another attempt to fabricate V2O5 nanosheets was successful through the endeavor from Li and co-workers.[125] They applied ultrasonic treatment followed by freeze-drying and annealing to prepare the 2D leaf-like nanosheets (Figure 6f) with the maximum specific capacity of 264 mA h g–1. The formations of the gel and cryogel during the ultrasonic treatment and freeze drying were keys to form well-shaped leaf-like 2D porous nansheets. The thickness of these nanosheets was around 60≈80 nm. The authors stated that the excellent performance of leaf-like nanosheets samples was believed to be related to the extremely large surface area and the relaxation of the cyclic strain due to charge/discharge processes owned by their porous structure. In 2013, a simpler route of liquid exfoliation was proposed by Rui et al.[130] The swelling interlayered space between layers of bulk V2O5 introduced by the formamide provided the opportunity to separate the layers by mechanical exfoliation such as ultrasonication. The primary XRD peak of (001) facets and the ultrathin morphology of the sample (Figure 6g) revealed the formation of single/multiple layers of virtually perfect crystalline structure. The maximum specific capacity of 292 mA h g–1 and 0.12% fading per cycle after applying 50 cycles demonstrated the competitive electrochemical performance of this ultrathin 2D nanosheet. This advantage was considered as the result of the huge specific surface area, tiny diffusion path, and the effective strain relaxation because of the 2D ultrathin morphology and the free-standing status.[130]
There are several good V2O5 electrodes with hierarchical micro-architectures which were published in the last three years. Mai et al. synthesized 3D nanoflakes-assembled

hollow-porous V2O5 quasi-microspheres using solvothermal treatment followed by annealing.[131] From the SEM image of Figure 6h, each quasi-microsphere had the outer diameter of 2≈5 µm with numbers of nanoflakes. The carbon microsphere provided the template of the growth of the layer of precursor nanoflakes during the solvothermal process. The annealing at 450 °C for 2 h released the residual of the ammonium group as well as the carbon template.[131] The resulting architecture of a hollow sphere embedded by a shell of nanoflakes offered the larger available space reserved for the volume change and the larger surface area of reactions, which led to the excellent performance of 283 mA h g–1 as the maximum specific capacity. Figure 6i exhibits another example of the hierarchical V2O5 micro-material for LIB electrodes. This 3D hierarchical hollow microspheres (diameter is about 22 µm) was prepared by Dong and co-worker using polyol process with calcination.[133] Each microsphere compromised numerous nanosheets of V2O5 with the well-defined crystalline structure of the orthorhombic phase. The nanosheets on the microspheres could offer larger surface area as well as the decreased lithium ion transport pathway, which brought out the favorable electrochemical performance of 275 mA h g–1 as the maximum specific capacity and the 0.06 % capacity fading per cycle after 200 cycles. Another hierarchical morphology of the 3D interconnected microspheres composed of ultralong nanobelts was manufactured by Rahman et al.[134] in 2015. The as-prepared microspheres illustrated in Figure 6j had the morphology resembled sea urchins. This is the consequence of the self-assembly of the vanadium oxide (VOx) nanoneedles in the electrolyte for days after the electrochemical anodization treatment. The annealing process enhanced the crystalline structure of the assembled VOx microurchins. The excellent performance of the maximum specific capacity of 280 mA h g–1 and 0.095% capacity faded per cycle after 200 cycles could be attributed to the enhanced lithium ion diffusion efficiency, larger surface area, and the improved buffering of the volume expansion/shrinkage.[134]
3.3. V2O5 Electrodes with Three Li+ Insertion
The practical trails to utilize the lithiation mode of three lithium ions insertion have not started until less than two decades ago. Initially, the insertion of three lithium ions into V2O5 electrodes were considered as the process with high risk to be irreversible since the formation of ω phase was stable.[91] In this case, the uneven plot of the dischange-charge curves were usually quite common for the V2O5 electrodes with three lithium ions insertion.[138–140] Nonetheless, some innovative breakthroughs have been achieved within around recent ten years. The development of the novel micro- and nano-structured V2O5 electrodes enhanced the first Columbic efficiency, which was much lower previously due to the irreversibility owned by the conventional bulk V2O5 electrodes. Table 5 summarizes recent experimental progress of V2O5 electrodes with three lithium ions insertion. More than half of the reviewed results could give a maximum specific capacity of 360 mA h g–1 or above, which implied the improvement of the performance of the micro- and nanostructured V2O5 electrodes. In 2008, Chou et al. prepared V2O5 nanomaterials by an ultrasonic-assisted hydrothermal method with annealing.[141] Three different morphologies of 2D nanoribbons (Figure 7a), 1D nanowires (Figure 7b), and 2D microflakes (Figure 7c) were formed based on the tuned condition of different surfactant usages. Among these three prepared samples, 2D nanoribbons using the nonionic surfactant of Brij 30 (C12H25(OCH2CH2)4OH) had the highest specific capacity of 430 mA h g–1. 1D nanowires (using surfactant of Triton X-100, t-octylphenyl-(OCH2CH2)xOH, x = 9≈10) and 2D microflakes (no added surfactants) could give the maximum specific capacities as 428 and 360 mA h g–1, respectively.[141] This interesting result could be correlated to three reasons. The first on was the increased specific surface area from 2D microflakes to 2D nanoribbons, which was equivalent with the more active reaction sites provided. Secondly, authors accomplished the drawing of the Arrhenius plot of three samples, the fitted results of the activation energies at 3.0 V were 63.3, 63.8, and 75.3 kJ mol–1 for nanoribbons, nanowires, and microflakes, respectively. The lowest activation energy of nanoribbons indicated the shortest diffusion length of lithium ions. The third one was from the XRD result. The precisely measured lattice parameters of three samples suggested the largest value of a owned by nanoribbons. This could result in the highest interlayered distance, which revealed the enhanced mobility of intercalated lithium ions.[141] Two examples of the hierarchical 1D nanowires/nanofibers results are illustrated in following panels of Figure 7. Mai and colleagues synthesized 1D ultralong hierarchical V2O5 nanowires through the electrospinning combined with annealing route.[142] During the process of the electrospinning, the zigzag connected nanorods of the NH4VO3 precursor formed on the substrate of aluminum foil after applying the high voltage (20 kV) with the assistance of Poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) as the

The PVA template and the ammonium group in NH4VO3 precursor were removed through the annealing process to get the product of V2O5 hierarchical nanowires, whose diameters were around 200 nm (Figure 7e). The maximum specific capacity of 390 mA h g–1 owned by these V2O5 hierarchical nanowires resulted from the enhanced surface reaction activity and the reduced self-aggregation of nanomaterials. Another kind of hierarchical porous 1D V2O5 nanofibers were prepared by Cheah et al.[87] They applied the similar electrospinning followed by the sintering method to fabricate the nanofibers. But different reagents of VO(acac)3 precursor and Poly (vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) template were used here. The as-prepared nanofibers were exhibited in Figure 7f,g. From Figure 7f it is simple to get that the diameter of nanofibers is approximately 500≈800 nm. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern shown in the transmission electron microscopic photo graph of Figure 7g reveals the porous polycrystalline structure of the V2O5 hierarchical nanofibers. Although the hierarchical architecture possessed by this sample, its performance of maximum specific capacity of 308 mA h g–1 and the 0.52% fading per cycle after 50 cycles were lower than other V2O5 electrodes with three insertion of lithium ions.[87] The main reason could be ascribed to the not obvious improvement of the specific

In general, three modes of the lithium ion(s) intercalation of V2O5 electrodes advanced the rapid development of the new microand nano-materials of V2O5. The innovative architectures such as hierarchical, porous, and large specific surface area synthesized by some controllable routes enhanced the capacity and cycling performance of V2O5 electrodes in all of three modes. 4. sections.heading: 4.1. Carbonaceous Materials as Additives of Electrodes
sections.text:
Carbon and carbonaceous materials such as graphite,[156] graphene,[45,157–159] carbon nanotubes (CNTs),[160–162] Fullerene,[163,164] graphene oxide (GO),[165–167] and reduced graphene oxide (rGO)[168–171] have been popular active additives to nanomaterials because of their massive distribution, low density, high specific surface area, excellent electrical and thermal conductivity, mechanical stability, and environmentally friendly components.[172] Before further discussion, it is necessary to point out that the term of “V2O5-based composite electrodes with carbonaceous materials” denotes to the micro- or nanocomposite electrodes where the carbonaceous materials are added during the synthesis. The electrodes with the carbonaceous component such as active carbon black added with the binder to prepare the slurry for the LIB cell assembly are not objects to be discussed in this review. Examples of the usage of such carbonaceous materials to the LIB as the additive of the V2O5-based composite electrodes in the most recent decade are listed in Table 6. From Table 6, it is noticed that different kinds of carbonaceous materials have been tested for the enhancement of the V2O5 electrodes. The maximum specific capacities of these examples span from 130 to 440 mA h g–1, which suggests that the usage of carbonaceous materials can benefit the performance of V2O5 electrodes at all three insertion modes. Carbon black and the rGO are two top-selected additives according to Table 6. Two specific examples are reviewed in the following paragraphs.
The first example is from the result that Rui and colleagues fabricated a kind of porous polycrystalline composite material by using the combination of V2O5 nanospheres and rGO sheets[189] in 2011. The ultrasonic-exfoliation-prepared GO sheets acted as a substrate to nucleate the V2O5•nH2O precursor in the liquid phase. Through the reduction during the following solvothermal process, both V2O5•nH2O precursor and GO substrate were reduced. Finally, the annealing procedure oxidized the reduced precursor back to V2O5, which meant the accomplishment of the composite. The well-defined XRD pattern of the as-annealed sample suggested the good crystalline structure of both V2O5 nanospheres and rGO substrate.[189] The TEM image of Figure 8a shows the morphology of the composite. A single V2O5 nanosphere had a diameter of ≈500 nm and the uneven brightness within spheres revealed the existence of numerous pores. The ultrathin rGO sheet supporting the nanospheres was clearly observable. This material had promising cycle and rate performance of 0.3% capacity faded per cycle when applying 50 cycles. The maximum specific capacity of 238 mA h g–1 could be attained simultaneously. Rui et al. summarized the reasons for these performance as: (1) the well-crystallized and highly-porous structure of V2O5 nanospheres offered more reaction sites and diffusion paths as well as the buffering of the volume changes during cycling; (2) the promising conductivity of the supported rGO sheets facilitated the efficient charge transport.
Another novel-structured V2O5–carbon composite material as LIB electrodes is shown in Figure 8b. The figure demonstrates the micron-sized and dodecahedron-shaped porous composite was the result of research from Zhang and co-workers in 2016.[180] Through the carbonization of the Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) as metal organic frameworks, the porous compound with the dodecahedron shape composed of carbon and cobalt nanoparticles formed. Following with the acid leaching and VOC2O4 infusion to remove the cobalt and introducing the vanadium compound, the porous dodecahedronshaped V2O5–carbon composite was prepared by calcination at last. The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping of a pair of as-calcinated dodecahedrons (Figure 8c) illustrated the even distribution of carbon, vanadium, and oxygen. This was the result of the uniform growth during the typical synthesis. This shape-specific porous composite also possessed excellent cyclic performance of 0.03% capacity faded per cycle after apply 800 cycles. The voltage window used here was 2.5≈4 V and the maximum specific capacity of 130 mA h g–1 proved the successful intercalation of one lithium ion. Better reaction conditions provided by the enlarged specific surface area, the easy diffusion pathway offered by numerous pores, and the homogenous distribution of the V2O5 active materials and highly conductive carbon frameworks are three main reasons for this good performance.

sections.heading: 4.2. Other Non-Carbonaceous Materials as Additives of Electrodes
sections.text:
The recent achievement of the V2O5-based composite electrodes other than carbonaceous materials can be categorized as composite with other transition metal compounds, polymeric materials, and other transition metals. Table 7 lists the recent published results reviewed in this article.
The additive of other transition metal compounds (hereinafter denoted as “TM”) is a popular choice to be introduced into V2O5 electrodes. Among the listed examples of the addition of other transition metal compounds (TM), one published result from Liu et al. in 2009 had an unprecedented morphology.[194] The innovative morphology of tin oxide (SnO2) nanoparticles deposited on a double-shelled V2O5 hollow nanosphere could be named as “nanocapsules” (Figure 8d).[194] V2O5 matrix and SnO2 nanoparticles formed at the same time during the solvothermal treatment inside the N,N-dimethyllformamide (DMF) solution at elevated pressure and temperature. The rough surface of nanocapsules due to the deposition of SnO2 nanoparticles and hollow core with double shells was apparent to see from the TEM photograph of Figure 8e. When this material was applied as cathode, authors used the voltage window of 2≈4 V, the maximum specific capacity of 212 mA h g–1 with the capacity fading of 0.36% per cycle was characterized. This proved the case of two inserted lithium ions. The novel nanoarchitecture which could offer shorter lithium ion diffusion lengths and more buffering to accommodate large volume changes resulted in the electrochemical performance. Moreover, the complicated and well-defined morphology with uniform size of nanocapsules and deposited nanoparticles prepared by such a facile

Polymers are another common family of materials which have been combined with V2O5 in order to prepare novel nanomaterials for LIB cells, particularly conductive polymers such as polyaniline (PANi)[195,201] and polypyrrole (PPy).[202,203,196,204] The reason is the exceptional electrical conductivity of conductive polymers as the result of the delocalized π-system backbone along their chains[208–211] can enhance the conductivity of the composite dramatically after introducing them into the V2O5 matrix. In this part, two examples of one V2O5/PANi and one V2O5/PPy are reviewed as representative results of the

Chen et al. prepared a kind of PANi-intercalated V2O5 layered nanocomposite using one-pot hydrothermal route.[195] As shown in Figure 8f, the as-prepared composite had the morphology of white fungus self-assembled from numerous thin nanosheets. Processes of the polymerization of aniline monomers and the subsequent intercalation into the interlayered space of bulk V2O5 during the hydrothermal treatment prompted the formation of this morphology.[195] The enhanced electrical conductivity and the improved surface area owing to the introducing of the PANi resulted in the electrochemical performance of the maximum specific capacity as 239 mA h g–1. For PPy, the recent work published by Noerochim and co-workers is a featured example.[196] After applying the vacuum filtration method, the as-prepared sample had the morphology of the paper-like and free-standing film whose thickness was around 10 µm. The densely-interconnected

The synergistic interactions between inorganic (V2O5) and organic (PPy), insulate (V2O5) and conductive (PPy) components were crucial to the excellent rate performance.
Transition metals are commonly used as conductive additives to enhance the electrochemical performance of V2O5based composite electrodes. Yu et al. reported a hierarchical nanobelt flowers (Figure 8h) potentially used in the cathode of lithium-ion batteries.[197] The morphology of microflowers was synthesized through the hydrothermal reaction of commercial V2O5 powders with Cu2+ ions doping. If the loading current density was set as 58.8 mA g–1, this nano-structured cathode could exhibit the electrochemical performance of 263 mA h g–1 as the maximum specific capacity with the capacity fading per cycle of 0.3% after using for 50 cycles. Due to the enhancement effect of the electrical conductivity from the doped Cu, the electrochemical performance of this cathode had been considerably improved. The significant decrease in charge transfer resistances via Cu doping (from 166.8 Ω to 62.4 Ω) was a convincing evidence of the improvement.[197] Another example of the V2O5–metal composite electrode was reported by Zheng and colleagues in 2015. They used nickel-mediated polyol process with calcination to fabricate the V2O5–Ni composite electrode.[132] As illustrated in Figure 8i, the morphology

of the as-prepared sample was hierarchical hollow microspheres. The energy dispersive spectroscopy image (Figure 8j) clearly demonstrated the uniform-spatial distribution of the Ni additive within a microsphere. This composite resulted in 266 mA h g–1 maximum specific capacity and capacity loss of 0.2% per cycle after 50 cycles when the applied current density was 300 mA g–1. The porous structure and hierarchical architectures, associated with increased electrical conductivity were attributed to favorable electrochemical performance as an LIB cathode.[132]
To summarize, both carbonaceous and non-carbonaceous additives are found to improve the electrical conductivity and create novel structures with larger specific surface area, subsequently the electrochemical performance of V2O5 electrodes.
5. Other VOx and VOx-Based LIB Electrodes
Besides the most common oxide of vanadium, i.e., vanadium pentoxide (V2O5), other types of vanadium oxides (VOx) can also be used for the LIB electrode preparation. These oxides may have single or multiple oxidation states of vanadium, crystalline or amorphous structure. While the related attempts have not become very popular since the complexity of the structure and the fabrication route of such oxides. In this review, nine representative examples of the VOx and VOx-based electrodes are listed (Table 8). Figure 9 illustrates three morphologies as examples. Firstly, a nanocomposite of Fe–VOx mixed-valence nanotubes was prepared through a sol–gel method with a hydrothermal route by Zhou et al. in 2012.[212] The morphology of hollow nanotubes with the diameter around 100 nm was clearly revealed from the TEM images of Figure 9a,b. The layered crystalline structure could be observed in the high-resolution TEM
image in Figure 9c. The interlayer spacing was around 1 nm. When applying the CV test within the window of 1.5≈4 V, three troughs at 3.04, 2.4, and 2.0 V implied that the insertion number of lithium ion for this Fe–VOx composite was three.[212] The charge-discharge cycling test obtained the data of the maximum specific capacity of 311 mA h g–1 and the 0.86% fading per cycle after 50 cycles. This result could be ascribed to the multilayered tubular structure of the composite as well as the ferric ion exchange process within the tubular walls. This structure could improve the proportion of pentavalent vanadium (V5+).[212]
The vanadium oxide which belongs to VnO2n+1 can be used as the LIB electrodes. In 2015, Ding and colleagues fabricated V6O13 nanotextiles as the electrode for LIBs.[217] They used hydrothermal method and mixing process to prepare the 1D V6O13 nanogrooves and assembled them into interconnected 3D nanotextiles. Figure 9d–f illustrates the morphology of the interconnected V6O13 nanotextiles from low to high magnifications. For one single nanogroove, the width was approximately 30 nm. Three reaction troughs were detected at 2.79, 2.46, and 1.73 V in the CV curve of nanotextiles from 1≈4 V window.[217] This suggested that three lithium ions were inserted into V6O13 step by step during the discharging. The crystalline structure of switching single and double vanadium oxide layers owned by V6O13[70] offered the space for the lithium ion intercalation. Due to the unique interconnected network feature of the V6O13 nanotextiles, the vacant grids inside the network could buffer the volume cyclic change of the nanogrooves and the interconnected structure was able to enhance the electron transporting. In this case, the maximum specific capacity of 326 mA h g–1 was obtained.[217] The tunable grid sizes by controlling the concentration of VOSO4 precursor could influence the electrochemical performance, which implied the significant role played by the arrangement of grids.

There are several research results that the vanadium oxide with lower valance of vanadium used as the LIB electrodes. For example, a nanostructure of nanosheet-assembled microspheres composed of V2O3–C composite (Figure 9g) was synthesized by Niu and co-authors in 2016.[220] The amorphous vanadium oxide nanosheets formed and aggregated into a hierarchical microspheres gradually due to the minimization of the surface energy. After applying the sintering in a nitrogen atmosphere, the crystalline V2O3 formed. The thin and crystalline feature of V2O3–C microsphere can be observed in Figure 9h. The CV test revealed three intercalation reactions occurred at the voltages of 1.98, 1.21, 0.61 V, which meant the insertion of three lithium ions. The excellent capacity and cyclic performance were suggested by the large maximum specific capacity of 795 mA h g–1 and the tiny capacity fading of 0.02% per cycle after 700 cycles. The reason could be summarized as the increased surface area, reduced ionic/electronic transport pathways, and the enhanced electrical conductivity due to the uniformly doped graphitized carbon.[220]

sections.heading: 6. Analysis of The Electrochemical Performance of V2O5 and V2O5-Based Electrodes
sections.text:
In previous sections, published results of both V2O5 and V2O5-based composite electrodes were reviewed and were categorized based on their lithium ions insertion modes and additive components. In this section, the electrochemical performance will be analyzed. Some empirical rules and corresponding principles will be summarized through data distribution and statistical analysis. The maximum specific capacity of an electrode is a significant index to evaluate the performance of the battery. In the case of the practical usage of batteries, the value of the maximum specific capacity is influenced by the charged/discharged current density, since the electron transport rate can affect the efficiency of the intercalation reaction at the interface of the electrode/electrolyte.[2] For the tabulated data of prior reported listed in Tables 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, the results with complete data
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 7, 1602545

Reproduced with permission.[217] Copyright 2015, American Chemical Society. g) SEM and h) TEM images with different magnifications of V2O3 nanosheet-assembled microspheres. www.advancedsciencenews.com
sets including four elements of maximum specific capacity, measured current density, cycle number, and capacity fading per cycle were selected to be investigated. In particular, the data points selected should have measured current density with the unit of milli-amperes per gram (mA g–1) for the purpose of consistency. Meanwhile, if the unit of C-rate in certain reviewed work denoted the measured current density, the value should be converted to the mA g–1 according to the insertion amount of the lithium ions. Detailed conversion methods were provided in the Supporting Information. According to the selected data, three plots of maximum specific capacity (mA h g–1) versus measured current density (mA g–1) of reviewed results are depicted as Figure 10 for a) V2O5 electrodes with three insertion modes, b) V2O5-based composite electrodes with different additive materials, c) hierarchical and un-hierarchical V2O5 and V2O5-based composite electrodes. Besides the capacity performance shown in Figure 10, the cyclic performance is also crucial for a battery due to this is the symbol to judge the battery if it can be used stably after a huge amount cycles.[42] The excellent cyclic performance is usually characterized by the low capacity percentage fading when the applied cycle number is very high. Therefore, three panels of the cycle number versus capacity fading per cycle (%) are plotted as Figure 11, which is also based on the previous categorization method. The detailed analysis of reviewed V2O5 and V2O5-based composite electrodes will be described in following subsections.

sections.heading: 6.1. Analysis of The Capacity Performance of V2O5 and V2O5-Based Composite Electrodes
sections.text:
Based on collected data, the maximum specific capacities are aggregated within the ranges of 130–147, 250–294, and 330–441 mA h g–1 for cases of one, two, and three lithium ions inserted. Figure 10a illustrates this rule. These ranges are close to the theoretical upper limits of 147, 294, and 441 mA h g–1, respectively. This suggests that the recent-developed V2O5 electrodes have acceptable capacity performance in all three insertion modes. Meanwhile, few results[88,94,103,114,115,155] with advanced capacity performance which obviously exceed the theoretical values can be found for all three modes. The unique as-fabricated porous, hierarchical, or high-specific-surface-area nanostructures as well as the small loaded current are the key points to obtain such exceptional performance. However, the increased wide distributions with the increased lithium ions insertion numbers can be observed from Figure 10a as well. This lesscondensed distribution trend is a symbol of the reduced performance stability among different samples with the same insertion mode, particularly for the three lithium ions insertion. The irreversible formation of the phase when applying the wide voltage window is the main reason. The capacity performance of V2O5-based composite electrodes are illustrated in Figure 10b. Among those 39 composite electrodes, 22 of them (56.4%) are located at the reference line of 294 mA h g–1 and adjacent regions. This shows that the two lithium ions insertion mode is the most adapted for not only V2O5 electrodes but also V2O5-based composite counterparts, especially the V2O5–carbon composite. Subsequently, referring to hierarchical or un-hierarchical V2O5 and V2O5-based composite electrodes, Figure 10c

exhibits the distribution of the scattered data points in the plot of maximum specific capacity versus the measured current density. The 60% of the total data points are located within a region of 30–300 mA g–1 of measured current density and 200–450 mA h g–1 of maximum specific capacity. For cases of all three lithium ions insertion modes, hierarchical electrodes have higher maximum specific capacities than un-hierarchical
counterparts. This phenomenon is more apparent if the insertion amount of lithium ions is two or three.
Now we investigate the relation between the capacity performance and the measured current density. According to three plots in Figure 10, it is worth noticing that the specific capacity of a LIB cell with V2O5 or V2O5-based composite electrodes is not only the function of lithium ion insertion modes, but also the function of the applied current density. A fitted golden dashed lognormal distribution curve is added in each panel of Figure 10 to reveal the regulation between the maximum specific capacity and the applied current density. The general expression of the probability distribution function of the lognormal distribution is written as Equation (2) as below.

here x is the measured current density, y is the maximum specific capacity, µ is the logarithmic mean value, and σ is the logarithmic standard deviation. The fitted values of mean value as exp(µ) and standard deviation as exp(σ) of all three panels in Figure 10 are tabulated in Table 9. After counting the data points underneath the fitted lognormal curve in each panel of Figure 10, around 80% of all data points (three exacts numbers are listed in Table 9) can be embedded in the fitted curves, i.e., the values of the maximum specific capacity are not greater than the value of f (measured current density) for 80% of all. From the 3-simga rule of the normal and lognormal distributions, the 68% of the total area underneath the fitted curve will have the highest value of the maximum specific capacity. The upper and lower boundaries of the measured current density for this “high capacity band” are exp(µ + σ) and exp(µ – σ), respectively. According to the fitted results in Table 9, the range of the applied current density for the “high capacity bands” of pure V2O5 electrodes, V2O5-based composite electrodes, and hierarchical and un-hierarchical electrodes are 31.07–407.88 mA g–1, 29.07–507.91 mA g–1, and 30.53–365.51 mA g–1, respectively. The “high capacity bands” are marked in yellow shaded areas in three corresponding panels of Figure 10. In general, optimal selection of the applied current density for V2O5 and V2O5-based composite LIB electrodes should be within the range of 30–500 mA g–1, i.e., the “high capacity bands”, in order to achieve the best capacity performance.

sections.heading: 6.2. Analysis of The Cyclic Performance of V2O5 and V2O5-Based Composite Electrodes
sections.text:
For the cyclic performance of V2O5 and V2O5-based composite electrodes, the typical distribution of one example with higher capacity fading per cycle has lower cycle number and vice versa can be observed straightforwardly in Figure 11. Because the product of the cycle fading per cycle and the cycle number denotes the total capacity loss, some investigations require the participation of the total capacity loss through the curve fitting. Here, the capacity fading per cycle is denoted by x, the cycle number is denoted by y, and the empirical total capacity loss is denoted by kL. The relation of kL = xy can be easily derived. The general expression of the reciprocal function shown in

www.advancedsciencenews.com
Equation (3) is used to fit the scattered dots in Figure 11a (pure V2O5 electrodes), 11b (V2O5-based composite electrodes), and 11c (hierarchical and un-hierarchical electrodes), where a and b are two coefficients.
1 y
a bx = + (3)
The optimal fitting curves for all three insertion modes of electrodes and V2O5–carbon, V2O5–TM, V2O5–polymer,V2O5– others composite, hierarchical, and un-hierarchical electrodes are plotted as dashed lines in Figure 11a–c. All corresponding coefficients of a and b are listed in Table 10. From this table, all categories of reviewed examples of V2O5 and V2O5-based composite electrodes have the values of a smaller than 0.01 and the b within the range of 0.015–0.062 1/% except the V2O5–polymer examples. The tiny values of a can be omitted to simplify the expression of Equation (3). In this case, the relation of 1/b ≈ xy can be derived and this suggests that the empirical total capacity loss kL is approximately equivalent with 1/b. Furthermore, values of empirical capacity retention kR = 1−kL are calculated and listed in the most right column of Table 10.
The cyclic performance of V2O5 and V2O5-based composite electrodes can be discussed using two newly proposed coefficients of kL and kR. These two coefficients describe the ability of electrodes made by one kind of material to maintain the capacity stably after long-term usage quantitatively. Although they are empirical coefficients, the meaning they can be interpreted is not limited to the empirical field. Due to the nature of kL ≈ xy, the values of both kL and kR reflect the intrinsic ability of capacity loss/retention of the material regardless of the value of applied cycle number. According to this, the smallest value possessed by the category of V2O5 electrodes with one lithium ion insertion can be correlated to the usage of the narrowest voltage window. The narrow window of 2.5–4 V can only provide the condition of the phase transformations of α → ε and ε → δ without successive formations of phases γ and ω. This process of phase transformation is able to eliminate the negative influence to the componential and structural stability of the electrode due to the cyclic changes of components and structure during charging/discharging procedures. As for the reason of the favorable values of kR owned by V2O5–carbon and V2O5–TM composites, this can be ascribed to the enhanced electrical conductivity along with the improved structural and thermal stability offered by the additive of carbonaceous materials and the synergistic effect of V2O5 and transition metal compounds with similar characteristics, respectively. Furthermore, through the comparison of the values of kR between hierarchical and un-hierarchical electrodes, the hierarchical design of the V2O5 and V2O5-based composite electrodes can obviously be expected to bring out the enhanced capacity retention after long-term cycling of the LIB cell. The higher specific surface area, the better surface reactivity, and the more available electron or ion transport pathways will be available. As such hierarchical micro- or nano-structures of electrodes are expected to improve the efficiency of the electrochemical reactions as well as eliminate the influence of the cyclic volume change during the charging and discharging. This is the key for hierarchical electrodes to have exhibit favorable cyclic performance.

sections.heading: 6.3. Comprehensive Performance of V2O5 and V2O5-Based Composite Electrodes
sections.text:
The general capacity and cyclic performance of V2O5 and V2O5-based composite electrodes have been analyzed separately in the previous two subsections. The general comparison of them can be visualized comprehensively and straightforwardly through the means of 3D bubble plot with plane projection and color mapping. Two panels of Figure 12 present this kind of plots. Figure 12a uses the bubbles and their plane projections with three different sizes denote the results of V2O5 electrodes with different lithium ion insertion numbers. A “rainbow spectrum” from colors of purple to maroon describes the increased cycle numbers of V2O5 electrodes from 5 to 1000. Bubbles of three insertion modes distribute as well-separated clusters at high, medium, and low vertical levels. There are two other tendencies that can be found from Figure 12a. The first is that most of examples with one lithium ion insertion have more cycles tested; the second is that a large amount of bubbles float in the region nearby the reference plane of measured current density of ≈100 mA g–1.
The overall performance of maximum specific capacity, capacity fading per cycle, measured current density, and the cycle numbers of four categories of V2O5-based composite electrodes are depicted as different-sized bubbles with different-sized plane projections in Figure 12b. The color spectrum from Spanish blue to scarlet denotes the increased cycle numbers from 25 to 3000. The colors of shades of blue of most of bubbles reveal the cycle numbers lower than around 150 of most of examples of V2O5-based composite electrodes. Over 80% bubbles are floating in the outer-right region, which illustrates that the maximum capacities of 200–300 mA h g–1 and the percentage capacity fading of 0.2–0.8% are typical for the V2O5-based composite electrodes. Such results collected from two 3D bubble plots not only are consistent with the previous 2D scattered dot plots, but also provide a more comprehensive demonstration of the performance of reviewed electrodes.
The comprehensive illustration of the electrochemical performance of both hierarchical and un-hierarchical V2O5 and V2O5-based composite electrodes is given in Figure 12c. In this figure panel, the larger bubbles and corresponding plane projections represent the published results of hierarchical electrodes; the smaller bubbles and smaller projected dots are those of un-hierarchical electrodes. The most straightforward feature of these bubbles is that most of them are located within a cuboid region. The boundaries of this cuboid are 10–1000 mA g–1 as measured current densities, 0–2% as capacity fading per cycle, and 147–441 mA h g–1 as maximum specific capacities. This regulation is consistent with our analysis in previous subsections of 6.1 and 6.2. Referring to the color of the bubbles, which are the demonstration of the cycle number scales, it is apparent that most hierarchical bubbles have colors of either green or olive and most of un-hierarchical bubbles have colors of blue and cyan. This implies that the tested cycle numbers of hierarchical electrodes are greater than those of un-hierarchical counterparts. The more competitive electrochemical performance of hierarchical electrodes are summarized through the 3D bubble plots with color mapping.

sections.heading: 6.4. Synthesis Methods of V2O5 and V2O5-Based Electrodes
sections.text:
Different micro- and nano-materials with different structures and components can be fabricated through highly diverse experimental approaches. Thus, the synthesis methods applied in reviewed results are worth investigating in this subsection. Based on collected literature, there are eight major routes reported and the percentage is the count based on all papers:
• Hydrothermal/solvothermal route (35.6 %) • Electrospinning (6.8 %) • Electrodeposition (4.2 %) • Wet-chemical synthesis (4.2 %) • Sol–gel process (3.4 %) • Polyol process (3.4 %) • Atomic layer deposition (2.5 %) • Chemical vapor deposition (0.8 %) • Other or combined methods (39.0 %)
A pie diagram shows these eight and other or combined experimental methods utilized in 118 published results is illustrated in Figure 13. Methods of hydrothermal/solvothermal route, electrospinning, electrodeposition, wet-chemical synthesis, polyol process, and sol–gel process are the ones have the top-six occupancy. The total occupancy of these six methods excesses one half (57.6%).
Among these experimental methods, it is worth noting that the most commonly used method, i.e., hydrothermal/ solvothermal routes occupy over one third in total, which is even higher than the summation of the rest of seven typical methods (25.4%). The widespread usage of the hydrothermal/ solvothermal routes has become acceptable for several decades.[221–224] The definition of the nomenclature of “hydrothermal” was from Byrappa and Yoshimura, who defined it as the heterogeneous chemical reaction in the presence of an
aqueous or non-aqueous solvent, elevated temperature, and the pressure higher than one atmosphere in a firmly closed vessel.[223] The main advantages of this method can be summarized as following items. Firstly, the crystalline structure of the prepared sample in the hydrothermal condition is welldefined.[224] Secondly, the elevated temperature and pressure are beneficial to form the structure/morphology which is difficult to be synthesized at the ambient condition.[221] Thirdly, the easy-to-manipulate conditions of temperature, pressure, and time length offer the possibility to form product with the identical components but different crystalline structures or morphologies.[225] Fourthly, the various conditions such as temperature and time length can assist researchers to investigate the formation mechanism of samples without worrying about other influences due to the enclosed condition.[195] Finally, the condition of the high-temperature liquid has higher possibility to form well-dispersed product suspended in the liquid without massive agglomeration.

sections.heading: 6.5. The Electrochemical Impedance Circuit Model
sections.text:
Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is a characterization method to analyze the mechanism of faradic reactions occurred in electrochemical systems.[226–228] The typical way of the characterization is detecting the changes of the output signal when applying a sinusoidal introducing voltage.[229] Any electrochemical system including corrosions,[230,231] batteries,[232–234] pseudocapacitors,[30,235,236] electrode-tissue interfaces[237–239] can be characterized by EIS analysis. An equivalent circuit can be construct based on the correlation between the detected EIS plot and the standard ones of characteristic circuits.[227] The most typical example is the circuit of a resistance and a capacitor components stacked in parallel (i.e., RC in parallel). The existence of
this circuit can be characterized by the detection of a semicircle arc in Nyquist plot and a peak in the φ versus ω (or f) of Bode plot.[240] Every single electrochemical system can be denoted by an equivalent circuit to represent its behavior of the electrochemical response, more than ten styles of the equivalent circuits have been proposed.[229]
For the reviewed results of V2O5 and V2O5based composite electrodes, some of them utilized the EIS plots of Bode and Nyquist[228] to analyze the faradic reactions and construct the model of equivalent circuits. Researchers can interpret the behavior during the reactions or phase transformations using these results. Figure 14 exhibits a schematic plot of the common Nyquist plot of the EIS analysis for most of the reviewed published results of V2O5 and V2O5-based composite electrodes. For the purpose of the straightforward comparison, two Nyquist curves of the bulk and micro- or nanostructured electrodes are respectively denoted by blue and red curves. There is an apparent feature in this Nyquist plot, which is that both curves have semicircle
Figure 13. The pie diagram of the percentage distribution of eight common fabrication methods and others to synthesize all V2O5 and V2O5-based composite electrodes reviewed in this paper.
